name: Chef Martin Yan
description: Martin Yan was born in Guangzhou, China, and began cooking at the age of 12. His father was in the restaurant business and Yan picked up the culinary arts through the family. He went to college in Hong Kong to earn a degree in culinary arts.

name: Chef Ken Hom
description: Hom ended up going to college at the University of California, Berkeley, and to help him earn some extra money while in school he began teaching cooking lessons. It became so widespread that he was eventually invited to the California Culinary Academy to teach.

name: Chef Cecilia Chiang
description: The friends eventually backed out of the deal, leaving Chiang with a restaurant and no experience running a business. She decided to stay and try her hand at the restaurant business, leaving her husband in China and having her kids fly out to the United States.

name: Chef Alvin Leung
description: Alvin Leung is an eccentric, self-taught chef who loves to push the boundaries of Chinese cooking. Many of his dishes are mixtures of cultures and he likes to call them “X-Treme Chinese” due to the largely inventive dishes that he serves.

name: Chef Danny Bowien
description: Danny Bowien began cooking as a normal part of life to help his family but soon became enamored with it as he found how it made people come together. He began working in many different restaurants in San Francisco and became so good during a stint at an Italian restaurant that he won first place in the 2008 Pesto World Championships.

name: Chef Peter Chang
description: Peter Chang attended culinary school in China before starting his career working in luxury hotels as the head chef. He won cooking competitions and began to attract a lot of attention for his delicious Szechwan cuisine, so much so that he was encouraged to move to the United States to try out his craft.

name: Maria Hernandez
description: Meet Chef Maria Rodriguez, a talented and passionate chef who has dedicated her life to the culinary arts. Maria grew up in a small town in Spain, where she developed a love for cooking at a young age. Her grandmother taught her how to make traditional Spanish dishes, and Maria quickly discovered that cooking was her true passion.
